VOL. XXXI. No. 29
ASSOCIATION OF COLLEGE
COMICS TO CONVENE
IN MARCH
Will Discuss Syndicate Relations and
Attempt to Organize
National Body

Syndication of material appearing in college comics to national
publications and newspapers will
probably be the main question before the delegates of the Association
of College Comics of the East when
they convene at Philadelphia on
March 5 and 6. Twenty-five humorous publications of universities in
the eastern part of the country will
send delegates to the meeting which
is being conducted under the auspices of the Punch Bowl of the
University of Pennsylvania.
Five Day Delegates

The Black and Blue Jay will be
represented by Maxwell Cone, Business Manager; Larkin H. Farinholt, Editor-in-Chief; and Leonard
Dalsemer, Advertising Manager.
At the present time, there seems
to be a great deal of dissatisfaction among college publishers regarding their dealings with College
Humor. Some claim that the jokes
have been changed by the reprinting magazine, and cuts and illustrations mixed. Others charge College
Humor with deliberately selling college comic material to a long list of
commercial publications, most of
which do not pay College Humor
for reprint rights. Members of the
executive committee of the association also argued that when the college comics decided on a stated reprint price, the quoted price did not
include any such privileges which
have later been assumed. Besides,
according to the committee's report,
many comics do not care to have
their material reprinted in certain
newspapers to which College Humor has granted such a right.
College Humor Accused

PRICE,5 CENTS

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 8, 1927

FINAL EXAMS TO BE
POSTPONED ONE WEEK
Final examinations will be
held this spring during the
week of May 30-June 7, a
week later than was announced
as graduation exercises will
not take place until June 14
this year.
According to Miss Davis, of
the Registrar's office, it has always been the custom to hold
these exercises on the second
Tuesday in June, with final
examinations two weeks previous to this. This year, by a
fortunate or unfortunate trick
of the calendar, the second
'Tuesday in June happens to
be the fourteenth, hence examinations from May 30-June
7.

Passano Made Senior
Banquet Chairman
Edward B. Passano was appointed chairman of the senior banquet
committee at a meeting of the class
held last Thursday. J. Henry Jarrett was selected chairman of the
class day committee at the same
time.
President Farinholt did not appoint full committees, but left the
selection of the remaining members
to the chairmen.
Treasurer Abraham made a re
port upon the class's finances.

Students Sign For
Hood Conference
Seven Hopkins students have already made arrangements to attend
the conference of the Student Christian Associations of Maryland, Delaware, and District of Columbia at
Hood College, Frederick, Md., February 11 to 13. The list includes
Lowell Ensor, Chairman of the Association. Three or four others
have signified their intention of
going.
The conference will deal with the
problems of Christians in the world
of today, including International
Relations, Science vs. Religion, and
other topics of great interest to students.

HOPES OF SWIMMING TEAM
ARE SHATTERED BY
EXAMINATIONS

1928 JUNE WEEK HEAD

Freshman Team to Have Attractive
Schedule; Varsity Will
Meet West Point

Rehearsals, Resumed Saturday, to
Continue Until Show

Coach Eddie Hill's sickness and
the loss of several men through ineligibility as a result of the recent
examinations have given a severe
blow to the prospects of the swimming team. Coach Hill is expected
back today and the candidates for
.the team practicing are very hard to
make up for their recent set-backs.
It is easier now to make the team
than at any time since the start of
the season and all men who have
any swimming ability are urged to
try out for it.

BOLTON ELECTED MANAGER
Examinations Deprive Club of
Services of Four Men

Frosh Team Organized

A freshman team has been organized for the first year men who are
not good enough for the varsity and
an attractive schedule is being arranged. All freshmen who make
their class squad will greatly improve their chance of getting a place
on the Varsity in future years.
The first meet of the season will
be held on February 19 at West
Point with the United States Military Academy. A tentative team
will be picked for the meet some
time this week. Positions are open
in every event, particularly the relays and dashes. Although nothing
is definite, it is expected that Captain Stone and Hemmeter will represent Hopkins in the diving events,
Hiss, in the backstroke, and Davis
in the 440. Hiss has already broken
the Hopkins record for the backstroke, but his time was made in
practice and will not be entered in
the records.

BARNSTORMERS CLUB
STARTS FINAL DRIVE

C. MAXWELL ARMOUR

Max Armour Appointed
Chairman Of 1928 June
Week Committee
C. Maxwell Armour was appointed chairman of the -1928 June Week
Committee by President Biddison
of the junior class at a meeting of
the class held last Friday. Other
members of the committee are
Charles Rohr, Ridgely Warfield,
David Kaufman, and Donald
White.
Two other committees were announced at the same time. Kenneth
Proctor received the appointment as
chairman of the junior dance committee, and Richard C. Griffith,
chairman of the banquet commitee.
The dance committee includes
Charles W. McElfresh, Osmar
Steinwald, Joseph Blandi, George
Berry, Cary Thompson, and George
P. Wagner.
Banquet Committee

The banquet committee includes
Fred Bauernschmidt, Charles Harris, Douglas Prahl, Jack Carroll,
Randolph Mengers, Leonard Dalsemer, and David Watson.
•
W. Browning Betz, a transfer
from Syracuse University, was
unanimously elected to membership
in the class.
The old question of dues was
brought up by Leonard Dalsemer,
class treasurer. Five dollars was set
as this year's assessment, payable
this week.

Harper's To Reprint
Jay Celebrity Article
When the Black and Blue ./(Tv set
off their "Celebrity Number" last
year it exploded with a loud report
into the literary atmosphere. Even
now answering echoes are coming
to the ears of the Jay editors. The
latest is a letter reporting that Harper and Brothers, prominent New
York publishers, are planning to
bring out in the Spring a book entitled "Best Laffs of 1926". In the
missive permission is asked of the
Tay to allow the reprinting of a
short skit by Charles G. Shaw, entitled "On the Crest of the Wave."
This article was written in the
form of a play and details the conversation of a group of collegians
aboard an ocean liner bound for
Europe.

Somewhat handicapped by a severe blow dealt by the mid-year examinations the Barnstormers Club
has plunged into the last long
stretch of work leading up to the
final presentation of "The Dictator"
on April 1 and 2, at the Lyric Theatre. Rehearsals were resumed Saturday afternoon, and following the
first rehearsal an important meeting of the Club members was held
in the Barn.
Donald A. Bolton was elected
Business Manager of the Club, and
Maxwell Bertuch was voted Production Manager. Both men have
been acting in the positions to which
they were elected throughout the
year filling vacancies from last year,
but final election was postponed until Saturday in order that their ability might be tested. An additional
obstacle arose when it was learned
later that Bertuch might not finish
out the college year.
Keys to Be Given

Although the Club members were
prohibited from wearing emblem
keys several years ago, it was decided to give the keys to each graduating member of the organization.
This plan will be carried out this
year.
The examinations deprived the
Barnstormers of the services of
Sands and Mallery from the acting
staff, while Hasbrouck has left college to go abroad. Brady decided to
try his luck at business, crippling
the Production Staff, and there is
a possibility that Bertuch will not
return.
Alternative Cast Picked

Coach Walter B. Swindell, Jr.
announced a list of those who have
shown the best talent. The final
cast will be chosen from this list:
President Rodgers, W. White,
Boynton, D. White, Caplan, Warfield, Blandi, Natt, Reese, Broening, Passano, Hoffman, Kolb, Gordon, McAll, Kreiling, Stissel, Northup and Berney.
The play is peculiar in that there
are many "extras" who will have
important parts. Those men who
were not put on the list and those
not chosen for the final cast will be
called back for these roles. A call
was sent out by the other staffs to
those who failed to make the cast
list, since there are many openings
on the Production, Publicity and
Art Staffs, and these furnish an opportunity for gaining membership
to the Club along different lines.
I. Evans Rodgers seems to be Mr.
Swindell's choice for the leading
part of the "dictator" of Porto Banos. President Rodgers has played
the part at almost ever-Sr rehearsal,
other aspirants failing to eclipse his
histrionic ability. The female roles,
however, are furnishing the greatest problem, as the best "actresses"
seem to be too tall to play female
characters.

The lecture system in American Universities has been the
recipient of much adverse criticism. in the past few years, justly
or unjustly. It has been attacked more from the outside than
from the inside, probably because its protagonists can see no acceptable substitute for it. And those who do look with disfavor
upon it'perhaps are afraid to become articulate for fear of losing
their jobs.
The chief objection to the lecture system is that it has become
an anachronism. It had its origin in the Middle Ages when books
were not generally available. Printing had not been developed,
and knowledge consequently had to be got directly from the professor rather than from his printed word.

Aldous Huxley, in an article in the current issue of Vanity
Fair, indicts the lecture system along with several other phases
of modern university methods. He remarks in one place that
he himself never attended more, than two lectures a week while
a student at Oxford. Incidentally, he believes that the methods
of teaching now current at Oxford and Cambridge (the tutorial
system) "comes more nearly to being rational than those employed by any other university with which I am acquainted".
Again, he says, "It would, of course, be. absurd to say that
lecturing is entirely useless; it is not. A course of lectures forms
an excellent introduction to individual study in any given subject. Moreover, men and women vary greatly in their capacity
to profit by the written word as opposed to the spoken word. . . .
For certain purposes, then, lectures are useful and necessary.
But to make a university education consist mainly of a course
of lectures is absurd."

And this absurdity is one reason for the partial degeneration
education. The average undergraduate attends
undergraduate
of
lectures, may or may not read textbook assignments that he receives, and with the exception of about one one-hundredth of one
percent, never looks for relevant or irrelevant reading matter
suggested (at long intervals, it is true) by the instructor.
Except for attendance at lectures, the average undergraduate student usually never gets to know the men who teach him.
The student is shy and reticent, (except for that obnoxious class
known as "handshakers") and the instructor in turn is cold and
uninviting.

FROM A UTILITARIAN STANDPOINT
What use is a college education? Time after time this question is asked by men in college, more often by those in their
Junior or Senior year than by men who have just begun. Several
answers can, of course, be given. Few will deny the advantages
of the cultural background which is formed by'a broad choice of
courses and by contact with the men of the faculty. It is practically self-evident. That a college course is essential to the man
who wishes to specialize, whether he intends to become a chemist
or a professor of English.
Sound as they are, these answers are not entirely satisfactory.
What,of the man who intends to "go into business"? He, by the
way, is the man who most often questions the value of a college
education. Let us suppose that he has completed his junior year.
Looking back on his three years he is bewildered and discouraged.
It seems that all he has gathered from his courses is a number of
random facts and a few theoretical principles. He sees men who
have gone to work immediately after finishing high school getting
ahead, and he sees college men who have failed to make good.
Taken as a whole, these facts are enough to make many a
man feel that he is wasting time at college. If he is of the type
that will always be a follower he is quite right; he is wasting time.
If, however, he is a man who will forge ahead, who will develop
into a leader, college can be of the greatest value to him. Courses
which he may consider trivial or pointless will give him a background which will enable him to correlate isolated facts and events
and in some measure to interpret their significance. The theories
which at the time he learned them he may have dismissed as valueless will take on a new importance. Whether he sells automobiles or manufactures shoes, he can look behind a mass of
detail and see the fundamental laws of supply and demand at
work. Not only will he see and understand these principles, he
may be able to predict effects from given causes.
The prestige which accompanies a diploma ought not to be
overlooked, even though the number of men finishing college is
infinitely greater than in the days when the tradition of the superiority of the college man was begun. In the last analysis, however, to use a platitude which has stood the test of time, a man's
success or failure rests with himself. A college education can
do no more than help a man; but that it is an advantage there is
no doubt.

According to the Oxford system, "perhaps the most fruitful
part of an Oxford or Cambridge education is that which is given
unofficially, in the course of the student's social relations with his
teachers. Intensive study is tempered by conversation. It is in
informal symposiums at night, over the fire, in the rooms of some
sympathetic and intelligent don, that the undergraduate conies to
be interested in, and familiar with, ideas. To discuss the problems of life with a highly cultured man, not too much older than
himself to be unable to understand his adolescent point of view,
is the most liberal education a youth can possibly have".
This is sorely lacking in American undergraduate schools.
Education is a cold, matter-of-fact proposition which becomes, not
the center of the student's life, but merely a phase of it. Well, I
see that my space has expired—more some other time.
D. H. M.

Thomas Arkle Clark, dean of
men at the University of Illinois,
and one of the best informed men
on college and fraternity affairs in
the country, has made a list of
things that he would do if he had
to go through college again. Were
Dean Clark to begin his college days
anew, he would:
1. Develop concentration—work
harder but not so long.
2. Learn to work while others
are around.
3. Put more stress on learning
how to get information than
upon the information itself.
4. Find more difficult tasks to do.
5. Learn to speak in public.
6. Learn to play some athletic
game.
7. Learn to do one line of work
particularly well,
S. Get better acquainted with his
instructors.
9. Take fewer courses which are
strictly practical.
10. Have an avocation which
would bring him into close
touch with men.
* * *

The University of California, including its southern branch, has the
largest enrollment in the United
States. This western college has
16,771 full-time students, Columbia
has 12,519 and Illinois 11,810. The
three schools hold the same ranking this year as they did last year.
University and college enrollment is
growing faster than it did before
the war. The reports from .over
180 institutions throughout the
country show an increase of about
11 per cent over last year.

President of George Washington
University recently said that fraternity life was the strongest feature
of modern colleges.

Miss Lizette Woodworth Reese and Mr.

O'Dunne in Charge

"The best poetry must be like
Lanier's, having poverty, lack of appreciation, and lack of recognition.
Poetry has fallen because it has too
many friends. The best poetry can
stand on its own legs. No kind of
weather can hurt it. It will last outside of hypocritical clubs and halfbaked critics," said Miss Lizette
Woodworth Reese, noted Baltimore
poet and honorary member of the
Tudor and Stuart Club, at last
Thursday's assembly, held in commemoration of Sidney Lanier.
Lanier Intensely Human

"We must look at poets in the
light of being human," declared
Miss Reese. "When I was a child,
emphasis was laid on persons; now
it is laid on things. Then there was
little philanthropy. What philanthropy there was, was human, a man
to man, woman to woman thing. No
organizations or movements or statistics, like those of today, were
known.
"When specialism came in as a
vogue, everything human was driven
out. Interest was in things. But
like Poe, Lanier had humanism. He
was not taught literature in any regular form. But he had the idea of
persons in opposition to things. His
feeling was the same for the poor
and rich, his enemies and his
friends.
"Most slovenly writing is due to
the fact that writers are in the clutch
of the thing they write about," con-.
tinued Miss Reese. "Lanier never
let the human idea get away from
him, and, as a result, he was mas-

They gave the girls a treat.
The occasion was the second
joint concert of the Musical Club
with the Glee Club of the Maryland College for Women at Lutherville last Friday evening.
Those who did the treating, of
course, were the banjo group, the
Jay orchestra, and the Hopkins
Glee Club. Maryland College
singers "retaliated", in some
measure, by a first-rate rendering of Deep River, a negro spiritual, and several other numbers.
The Black and Blue singers
started off the concert with the
university ode, gave a dignified interpretation of the stately Pilgrim's Chorus from "Tannhauser",
and ended this particular entree
with the rollicking "Old Man
Noah".
Following the campus warblers came a number of snappy
pieces, by the Banjo Club, under
the capable direction of Mr. Gebelein. Then loose-fingered Carl
Lausch appeared on deck with the
popular Staccato Etude of Friml.
The Hawaiian troupe, full of
ukeleles and guitars, put on the
softly and slowly melodious
"Dreamy Days" with their usual
intelligent rendering. "My Little
Banjo", an engaging little negro
song, sung by the Glee Club, was
next.
Versatile "Bill" Rodgers then
made his initial bow of the evening. He beamed around the audience with all-inclusive good nature, which is notoriously infectious. He soon had the girls
showing their dimples, if any, in
pleasant smiles. That went a
great deal toward breaking the
ice, if any, for the informal affair
which followed the concert.
After the entertainment a la
Rodgers the Banjo Club came on
again and played Beethoven's
Minuet in G, with an encore.
Steinwald, accompanied by
Lausch, brought his violin to life
in his usual masterful style. Miss
Leah Durst, of the Maryland College, then gave a reading entitled
"When Men Propose" which met
with ready approval. The Blue
Jay Orchestra next came in tor
their share of the evening's entertainment and were greeted with
instant and spontaneous applause.
The Jay numbers included several excellent selections from
Cookman Boyd's xylophone. The
Glee Club put the finishing
touches to the program with
"The Bells of St. Mary's."
Following the concert the Blue
Jays got into action on the ballroom floor, and the struggle was
on. All formalities were called off
and introductions were made to
order so that in a surprisingly
short time Maryland College and
Johns Hopkins became acquainted and spent the rest of the evening in the usual routine of dancing, wise-cracking and "breaking".
The next trip of the Musical
Clubs will be to Wilmington this
Friday.

ASSOCIATION OF COLLEGE
COMICS TO CONVENE
IN MARCH
Will Discuss Syndicate Relations and
Attempt to Organize
National Body

Syndication of material appearing in college comics to national
publications and newspapers will
probably be the main question before the delegates of the Association
of College Comics of the East when
they convene at Philadelphia on
March 5 and 6. Twenty-five humorous publications of universities in
the eastern part of the country will
send delegates to the meeting which
is being conducted under the auspices of the Punch Bowl of the
University of Pennsylvania.
Five Day Delegates

The Black and Blue Jay will be
represented by Maxwell Cone, Business Manager; Larkin H. Farinholt, Editor-in-Chief; and Leonard
Dalsemer, Advertising Manager.
At the present time, there seems
to be a great deal of dissatisfaction among college publishers regarding their dealings with College
Humor. Some claim that the jokes
have been changed by the reprinting magazine, and cuts and illustrations mixed. Others charge College
Humor with deliberately selling college comic material to a long list of
commercial publications, most of
which do not pay College Humor
for reprint rights. Members of the
executive committee of the association also argued that when the college comics decided on a stated reprint price, the quoted price did not
include any such privileges which
have later been assumed. Besides,
according to the committee's report,
many comics do not care to have
their material reprinted in certain
newspapers to which College Humor has granted such a right.
College Humor Accused

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 8, 1927

FINAL EXAMS TO BE
POSTPONED ONE WEEK
Final examinations will be
held this spring during the
week of May 30-June 7, a
week later than was announced
as graduation exercises will
not take place until June 14
this year.
According to Miss Davis, of
the Registrar's office, it has always been the custom to hold
these exercises on the second
Tuesday in June, with final
examinations two weeks previous to this. This year, by a
fortunate or unfortunate trick
of the calendar, the second
'Tuesday in June happens to
be the fourteenth, hence examinations from May 30-June
7.

Passano Made Senior
Banquet Chairman
Edward B. Passano was appointed chairman of the senior banquet
committee at a meeting of the class
held last Thursday. J. Henry Jarrett was selected chairman of the
class day committee at the same
time.
President Farinholt did not appoint full committees, but left the
selection of the remaining members
to the chairmen.
Treasurer Abraham made a re
port upon the class's finances.

Students Sign For
Hood Conference
Seven Hopkins students have already made arrangements to attend
the conference of the Student Christian Associations of Maryland, Delaware, and District of Columbia at
Hood College, Frederick, Md., February 11 to 13. The list includes
Lowell Ensor, Chairman of the Association. Three or four others
have signified their intention of
going.
The conference will deal with the
problems of Christians in the world
of today, including International
Relations, Science vs. Religion, and
other topics of great interest to students.

ARE SHATTERED BY
EXAMINATIONS

1928 JUNE WEEK HEAD

Freshman Team to Have Attractive
Schedule; Varsity Will
Meet West Point

Rehearsals, Resumed Saturday, to
Continue Until Show

Coach Eddie Hill's sickness and
the loss of several men through ineligibility as a result of the recent
examinations have given a severe
blow to the prospects of the swimming team. Coach Hill is expected
back today and the candidates for
.the team practicing are very hard to
make up for their recent set-backs.
It is easier now to make the team
than at any time since the start of
the season and all men who have
any swimming ability are urged to
try out for it.

BOLTON ELECTED MANAGER
Examinations Deprive Club of
Services of Four Men

Frosh Team Organized

A freshman team has been organized for the first year men who are
not good enough for the varsity and
an attractive schedule is being arranged. All freshmen who make
their class squad will greatly improve their chance of getting a place
on the Varsity in future years.
The first meet of the season will
be held on February 19 at West
Point with the United States Military Academy. A tentative team
will be picked for the meet some
time this week. Positions are open
in every event, particularly the relays and dashes. Although nothing
is definite, it is expected that Captain Stone and Hemmeter will represent Hopkins in the diving events,
Hiss, in the backstroke, and Davis
in the 440. Hiss has already broken
the Hopkins record for the backstroke, but his time was made in
practice and will not be entered in
the records.

BARNSTORMERS CLUB
STARTS FINAL DRIVE

C. MAXWELL ARMOUR

Max Armour Appointed
Chairman Of 1928 June
Week Committee
C. Maxwell Armour was appointed chairman of the -1928 June Week
Committee by President Biddison
of the junior class at a meeting of
the class held last Friday. Other
members of the committee are
Charles Rohr, Ridgely Warfield,
David Kaufman, and Donald
White.
Two other committees were announced at the same time. Kenneth
Proctor received the appointment as
chairman of the junior dance committee, and Richard C. Griffith,
chairman of the banquet commitee.
The dance committee includes
Charles W. McElfresh, Osmar
Steinwald, Joseph Blandi, George
Berry, Cary Thompson, and George
P. Wagner.
Banquet Committee

The banquet committee includes
Fred Bauernschmidt, Charles Harris, Douglas Prahl, Jack Carroll,
Randolph Mengers, Leonard Dalsemer, and David Watson.
•
W. Browning Betz, a transfer
from Syracuse University, was
unanimously elected to membership
in the class.
The old question of dues was
brought up by Leonard Dalsemer,
class treasurer. Five dollars was set
as this year's assessment, payable
this week.

Harper's To Reprint
Jay Celebrity Article
When the Black and Blue ./(Tv set
off their "Celebrity Number" last
year it exploded with a loud report
into the literary atmosphere. Even
now answering echoes are coming
to the ears of the Jay editors. The
latest is a letter reporting that Harper and Brothers, prominent New
York publishers, are planning to
bring out in the Spring a book entitled "Best Laffs of 1926". In the
missive permission is asked of the
Tay to allow the reprinting of a
short skit by Charles G. Shaw, entitled "On the Crest of the Wave."
This article was written in the
form of a play and details the conversation of a group of collegians
aboard an ocean liner bound for
Europe.

Somewhat handicapped by a severe blow dealt by the mid-year examinations the Barnstormers Club
has plunged into the last long
stretch of work leading up to the
final presentation of "The Dictator"
on April 1 and 2, at the Lyric Theatre. Rehearsals were resumed Saturday afternoon, and following the
first rehearsal an important meeting of the Club members was held
in the Barn.
Donald A. Bolton was elected
Business Manager of the Club, and
Maxwell Bertuch was voted Production Manager. Both men have
been acting in the positions to which
they were elected throughout the
year filling vacancies from last year,
but final election was postponed until Saturday in order that their ability might be tested. An additional
obstacle arose when it was learned
later that Bertuch might not finish
out the college year.
Keys to Be Given

Although the Club members were
prohibited from wearing emblem
keys several years ago, it was decided to give the keys to each graduating member of the organization.
This plan will be carried out this
year.
The examinations deprived the
Barnstormers of the services of
Sands and Mallery from the acting
staff, while Hasbrouck has left college to go abroad. Brady decided to
try his luck at business, crippling
the Production Staff, and there is
a possibility that Bertuch will not
return.
Alternative Cast Picked

Coach Walter B. Swindell, Jr.
announced a list of those who have
shown the best talent. The final
cast will be chosen from this list:
President Rodgers, W. White,
Boynton, D. White, Caplan, Warfield, Blandi, Natt, Reese, Broening, Passano, Hoffman, Kolb, Gordon, McAll, Kreiling, Stissel, Northup and Berney.
The play is peculiar in that there
are many "extras" who will have
important parts. Those men who
were not put on the list and those
not chosen for the final cast will be
called back for these roles. A call
was sent out by the other staffs to
those who failed to make the cast
list, since there are many openings
on the Production, Publicity and
Art Staffs, and these furnish an opportunity for gaining membership
to the Club along different lines.
I. Evans Rodgers seems to be Mr.
Swindell's choice for the leading
part of the "dictator" of Porto Banos. President Rodgers has played
the part at almost ever-Sr rehearsal,
other aspirants failing to eclipse his
histrionic ability. The female roles,
however, are furnishing the greatest problem, as the best "actresses"
seem to be too tall to play female
characters.

The lecture system in American Universities has been the
recipient of much adverse criticism. in the past few years, justly
or unjustly. It has been attacked more from the outside than
from the inside, probably because its protagonists can see no acceptable substitute for it. And those who do look with disfavor
upon it'perhaps are afraid to become articulate for fear of losing
their jobs.
The chief objection to the lecture system is that it has become
an anachronism. It had its origin in the Middle Ages when books
were not generally available. Printing had not been developed,
and knowledge consequently had to be got directly from the professor rather than from his printed word.

Aldous Huxley, in an article in the current issue of Vanity
Fair, indicts the lecture system along with several other phases
of modern university methods. He remarks in one place that
he himself never attended more, than two lectures a week while
a student at Oxford. Incidentally, he believes that the methods
of teaching now current at Oxford and Cambridge (the tutorial
system) "comes more nearly to being rational than those employed by any other university with which I am acquainted".
Again, he says, "It would, of course, be. absurd to say that
lecturing is entirely useless; it is not. A course of lectures forms
an excellent introduction to individual study in any given subject. Moreover, men and women vary greatly in their capacity
to profit by the written word as opposed to the spoken word. . . .
For certain purposes, then, lectures are useful and necessary.
But to make a university education consist mainly of a course
of lectures is absurd."

FROM A UTILITARIAN STANDPOINT
What use is a college education? Time after time this question is asked by men in college, more often by those in their
Junior or Senior year than by men who have just begun. Several
answers can, of course, be given. Few will deny the advantages
of the cultural background which is formed by'a broad choice of
courses and by contact with the men of the faculty. It is practically self-evident. That a college course is essential to the man
who wishes to specialize, whether he intends to become a chemist
or a professor of English.
Sound as they are, these answers are not entirely satisfactory.
What,of the man who intends to "go into business"? He, by the
way, is the man who most often questions the value of a college
education. Let us suppose that he has completed his junior year.
Looking back on his three years he is bewildered and discouraged.
It seems that all he has gathered from his courses is a number of
random facts and a few theoretical principles. He sees men who
have gone to work immediately after finishing high school getting
ahead, and he sees college men who have failed to make good.
Taken as a whole, these facts are enough to make many a
man feel that he is wasting time at college. If he is of the type
that will always be a follower he is quite right; he is wasting time.
If, however, he is a man who will forge ahead, who will develop
into a leader, college can be of the greatest value to him. Courses
which he may consider trivial or pointless will give him a background which will enable him to correlate isolated facts and events
and in some measure to interpret their significance. The theories
which at the time he learned them he may have dismissed as valueless will take on a new importance. Whether he sells automobiles or manufactures shoes, he can look behind a mass of
detail and see the fundamental laws of supply and demand at
work. Not only will he see and understand these principles, he
may be able to predict effects from given causes.
The prestige which accompanies a diploma ought not to be
overlooked, even though the number of men finishing college is
infinitely greater than in the days when the tradition of the superiority of the college man was begun. In the last analysis, however, to use a platitude which has stood the test of time, a man's
success or failure rests with himself. A college education can
do no more than help a man; but that it is an advantage there is
no doubt.

According to the Oxford system, "perhaps the most fruitful
part of an Oxford or Cambridge education is that which is given
unofficially, in the course of the student's social relations with his
teachers. Intensive study is tempered by conversation. It is in
informal symposiums at night, over the fire, in the rooms of some
sympathetic and intelligent don, that the undergraduate conies to
be interested in, and familiar with, ideas. To discuss the problems of life with a highly cultured man, not too much older than
himself to be unable to understand his adolescent point of view,
is the most liberal education a youth can possibly have".
This is sorely lacking in American undergraduate schools.
Education is a cold, matter-of-fact proposition which becomes, not
the center of the student's life, but merely a phase of it. Well, I
see that my space has expired—more some other time.
D. H. M.

Thomas Arkle Clark, dean of
men at the University of Illinois,
and one of the best informed men
on college and fraternity affairs in
the country, has made a list of
things that he would do if he had
to go through college again. Were
Dean Clark to begin his college days
anew, he would:
1. Develop concentration—work
harder but not so long.
2. Learn to work while others
are around.
3. Put more stress on learning
how to get information than
upon the information itself.
4. Find more difficult tasks to do.
5. Learn to speak in public.
6. Learn to play some athletic
game.
7. Learn to do one line of work
particularly well,
S. Get better acquainted with his
instructors.
9. Take fewer courses which are
strictly practical.
10. Have an avocation which
would bring him into close
touch with men.

"The best poetry must be like
Lanier's, having poverty, lack of appreciation, and lack of recognition.
Poetry has fallen because it has too
many friends. The best poetry can
stand on its own legs. No kind of
weather can hurt it. It will last outside of hypocritical clubs and halfbaked critics," said Miss Lizette
Woodworth Reese, noted Baltimore
poet and honorary member of the
Tudor and Stuart Club, at last
Thursday's assembly, held in commemoration of Sidney Lanier.
Lanier Intensely Human

"We must look at poets in the
light of being human," declared
Miss Reese. "When I was a child,
emphasis was laid on persons; now
it is laid on things. Then there was
little philanthropy. What philanthropy there was, was human, a man
to man, woman to woman thing. No
organizations or movements or statistics, like those of today, were
known.
"When specialism came in as a
vogue, everything human was driven
out. Interest was in things. But
like Poe, Lanier had humanism. He
was not taught literature in any regular form. But he had the idea of
persons in opposition to things. His
feeling was the same for the poor
and rich, his enemies and his
friends.
"Most slovenly writing is due to
the fact that writers are in the clutch
of the thing they write about," con-.
tinued Miss Reese. "Lanier never
let the human idea get away from
him, and, as a result, he was mas-

They gave the girls a treat.
The occasion was the second
joint concert of the Musical Club
with the Glee Club of the Maryland College for Women at Lutherville last Friday evening.
Those who did the treating, of
course, were the banjo group, the
Jay orchestra, and the Hopkins
Glee Club. Maryland College
singers "retaliated", in some
measure, by a first-rate rendering of Deep River, a negro spiritual, and several other numbers.
The Black and Blue singers
started off the concert with the
university ode, gave a dignified interpretation of the stately Pilgrim's Chorus from "Tannhauser",
and ended this particular entree
with the rollicking "Old Man
Noah".
Following the campus warblers came a number of snappy
pieces, by the Banjo Club, under
the capable direction of Mr. Gebelein. Then loose-fingered Carl
Lausch appeared on deck with the
popular Staccato Etude of Friml.
The Hawaiian troupe, full of
ukeleles and guitars, put on the
softly and slowly melodious
"Dreamy Days" with their usual
intelligent rendering. "My Little
Banjo", an engaging little negro
song, sung by the Glee Club, was
next.
Versatile "Bill" Rodgers then
made his initial bow of the evening. He beamed around the audience with all-inclusive good nature, which is notoriously infectious. He soon had the girls
showing their dimples, if any, in
pleasant smiles. That went a
great deal toward breaking the
ice, if any, for the informal affair
which followed the concert.
After the entertainment a la
Rodgers the Banjo Club came on
again and played Beethoven's
Minuet in G, with an encore.
Steinwald, accompanied by
Lausch, brought his violin to life
in his usual masterful style. Miss
Leah Durst, of the Maryland College, then gave a reading entitled
"When Men Propose" which met
with ready approval. The Blue
Jay Orchestra next came in tor
their share of the evening's entertainment and were greeted with
instant and spontaneous applause.
The Jay numbers included several excellent selections from
Cookman Boyd's xylophone. The
Glee Club put the finishing
touches to the program with
"The Bells of St. Mary's."
Following the concert the Blue
Jays got into action on the ballroom floor, and the struggle was
on. All formalities were called off
and introductions were made to
order so that in a surprisingly
short time Maryland College and
Johns Hopkins became acquainted and spent the rest of the evening in the usual routine of dancing, wise-cracking and "breaking".
The next trip of the Musical
Clubs will be to Wilmington this
Friday.
